description: From Latin impervius (“that cannot be passed through”), from in- (“not”) + pervius (“letting things through”).

adjectives.description: impervious (comparative more impervious, superlative most impervious)

entries.meaning: Unaffected or unable to be affected by something.
examples: The man was completely impervious to the deception we were trying.

entries.meaning: Preventive of any penetration; impenetrable, impermeable, particularly of water.
examples: Although patchworked and sagging, the roof proved impervious to the weather.
The old car seemed to be impervious to the wear and tear of age.
